item.title: Why I'm Not Voting This Year
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded: When I turned 18 in June, I was pretty excited to finally be allowed to vote. Gradually though, I became glad that voting was not the requirement of every citizen, but a right we can choose to utilize. Election season finally got under full swing, and it became clearer how dysfunctional everything was in Washington. I don't want to endorse the waste and corruption that our government has become or, more importantly, the belief that whoever is elected will be savior to our "failing" nation. No matter how much they talk about it, I find it difficult to believe that either candidate will be able to make many of the changes they promise, as hard as they might try. No matter what side you support, the candidate you favor will in the end only be marginally superior to his opponent. The most astounding thing to me is the assumption a lot of people make that they know government policy better than the candidates do. They act like the candidates are stupid. A lot of this is the media's fault. They sensationalize every gaffe and soundbite, because it makes for more exciting news. Because politics is boring. It's policy and jargon and numbers. Why discuss that when we can pretend that one of the two people most likely to become the leader of the free world doesn't know the geographic relationship between a nuclear enemy and its closest ally? I honestly believe though that it's tough to get as far as these candidates have gotten without being smarter or more politically versed than the average high school senior. The ridiculous thing is that there are so many legitimate arguments against both sides that we shouldn't have to resort to the pettiness that most political conversations have become. It's like when people correct each other's grammar on the internet. Sure, you might technically be correct. But if that's the argument you choose it implies that it's one of the best arguments you have. It also weakens all your other arguments. Instead of your arguments being judged cumulatively, they're averaged together. So stopping after 2 strong points would be better than adding in a 3rd mediocre one (This is called the Presenter's paradox it's actually pretty interesting). So stay away from those viral Facebook posts please. If you think for like 2 seconds after you see them, I'm sure you'll find the logical fallacy or omitted data. My belief is that government should take on problems that only it can solve. And as a full blown capitalist, I think that category only contains a handful of problems. More than anything though it should stay away from problems it doesn't understand (e.g. SOPA). For the most part, I want a government that does less, not more. But honestly, I'm just glad that we live in a country where our success is determined not by the actions of the government but by our own (And that I've found a way to feel superior to everyone). In the end, isn't that all we can really ask for? Mayank Jain is the founder of the Super PAC Leader of the PAC, so his political opinion is worth more than yours. Follow him on twitter @mjmayank1.

item.title: How to be good at Twitter
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
All tweets should fall under one of the following categories:1. "I never thought about it like that before" 2. "I've always wanted to say that but I just didn't have the words" 3. "I hate you and everything you stand for" http://whereiskatima.wordpress.com/about/ http://www.thomaslfriedman.com/bookshelf/longitudes-and-attitudes
How to use twitter
too many people tweet like specific things that are happening in thier lives
which isn't the point
theres a couple ways to tweet
either you tweet something that people can relate to
which could be and usually is something that happened in your life
but you have to phrase it in a way that allows people to care about it
or you can tweet your thoughts
but they have to be either insightful
thought provoking
or clever
Mayank
im talking about good ways to tweet
me
oh ok
so ur saying those are the ways to make ur twitter meaningful?
Mayank
yeah
me
i buy dat
this is assuming you're tweeting as yourself of course
obviously you could take on a persona
and only tweet about a specific topic
in which case you're allowed slightly more leeway in tweeting about specific things that happen to you as long as its relevant to said topic
fair enoughhhh
but what if people just want to be social
thats what facebook is for
well that basically limits your followers to people that know you personally

item.title: The Best Vacation I Ever Took
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded: A few weeks before coming to intern at Youth Venture, I was in the Dominican Republic volunteering at an Hope of a Child orphanage, with a group of eight of my friends. While this was my first time at the orphanage, my friend had volunteered there a couple times before. After hearing for two years about how awesome the experience was, I knew that I had to go. Once there we spent a week organizing a sport’s camp, teaching English, and playing with the kids.Though the kids at the orphanage grew up in situations less privileged from my own, they amazed me with their desire to learn, both in the classroom and outside it. I learned a lot during my time there as well. One thing that surprised me was the amount of supplies the orphanage already had. They had cabinets full of school supplies and shelves full of backpacks. They had buckets full of soccer balls and basketballs and tennis balls and baseballs. A lot of the things that we typically donate to charity drives were already there. What they actually need are volunteers to actually implement those supplies. They need people to spend time and organize sports camps. They need volunteers to stand in front of the chalkboard and teach English to the kids. That’s not to say that resources aren’t necessary. Since the last time my friend visited, the orphanage had lost significant funding. They are now only able to support 16 kids, far fewer than the 48 who had lived there the previous year. However, while the resources are always a necessity, it became clear through our interactions that they truly valued wasn’t our stuff, but our time. Now, back home, my friends and I have been doing as much as we can from abroad, raising money so the orphanage can support more children and helping develop their website so that they can encourage more people to volunteer. The main thing I realized was that when we only make a small deviation from our daily routine we can only make a small difference. When we really travel outside our comfort zone (figuratively or physically) that’s when we can have the biggest impact. Mayank Jain (@mjmayank1) is a rising freshman at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and will be studying Computer Science in the Fall. A Northern Virginia native, he has worked with organizations such as iCAREweCARE, Jwalamukhi, and Ashoka’s Youth Venture that work on getting students involved in creating social impact through entrepreneurship.

item.title: How to Cut in Line
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded: This is the first in a series of posts entitled Nice Guys Finish Last There are several techniques to successfully cutting in line without having anybody say anything to you. They come with different levels of confidence needed to execute them, and different levels of legitimacy. I’ve broken them down into 4 types: The Chat and Cut – The Chat and Cut is used when someone you know is already in line. Just walk straight up to them and engage in conversation as if they had been saving the spot for you the whole time. You probably already used this one on a regular basis so there’s no point going into it in too much detail. Just act natural and nobody is really going to say anything to you for joining your friend unless they’re super anal or the line is for something of limited quantity. The Wanderer – The Wanderer is performed by entering the line and then pretending to search for someone further up. Eventually you stop looking and slowly drop back in line easing your way in. Be genuinely confused as you begin your search. Tilt your head up, peer over people’s heads, and scrunch your eyebrows. This tactic can only be used in high volume lines (usually the kind that wind side to side). It’s not going to be plausible if you can see everyone that’s standing in line just by being on the side. Once you’re far enough forward to enter the line, stop and stand a little on the side and let people pass you. Once a few people have passed you, then get back in line. This gives the appearance that you were actually in front and are now dropping back. This is a good tactic for amusement parks. The Clean Cut – The Clean Cut is actually an extremely simple maneuver, yet very difficult to pull off. It’s entirely mental. The Clean Cut simply requires you walking straight to the front of the line as if you are entitled to that privilege, and would be extremely confused if anyone questioned your right to do so. This cut is effective in lines that only require one quick point of contact (i.e. scanning a ticket). It’s slightly more difficult in a buffet type of line, as any lingering can blow your cover. This is probably the hardest of the cuts to pull off, because of the extreme confidence required, but is often times most effective. Even the slightest hesitation can tip your hand. Being dressed professionally is also strongly correlated with the success of this tactic. If you are wearing a tie, you might also want to consider flipping it over your shoulder, indicating that you are in such a hurry that doing something as inconsequential as fixing your tie would be a waste of time. The “I’m in a Hurry” Cut – Also known as the “I Have a Flight to Catch”, the “I’m in a Hurry” Cut simply requires inventing a reason for why you are cutting someone in line and telling them that you’re going to have to cut them. It’s usually not even necessary to come up with an actual reason. Just stating that you’re in a hurry is probably good enough. It is best to be firm yet polite, allowing other line-goers to empathize with you. Say ‘excuse me’ or utter a quick apology for the inconvenience. This is obviously best used when you are actually in a hurry. With these techniques in hand you should be able to cut in any line long enough to be worth cutting. Different situations might require different tactics – sometimes even a combination of the techniques (to be honest the majority of people would be too scared to call you out on it no matter how you do it), but with the right read and enough bravado, you’ll never have to wait in line again. Remember though: with great power comes great responsibility. Don't abuse it. Have any other techniques? Had success with these ones? Let us know in the comments. Mayank Jain is completely unqualified to be writing this. For more of his unsolicited opinions, follow him on twitter @mjmayank1

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: How to Get Your Own Seat on the Bus ← Mayank's Blog
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] This is a continuation of the series Nice Guys Finish Last. The previous post can be found at “How to Cut in Line” [...]
don't you feel bad for the people you cut?

item.title: A Conversation About the Future of TJ
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
On September 19th,  Amie York Trebing posed the rather innocuous question in the TJHSST Alumni group on Facebook. "[Are] there many 2nd generation TJ students?" she asked. 

Are we still #1?
I responded (somewhat exorbitantly), "Unless there's a monumental shift in the direction of the school, i dont think too many students graduating in the recent years wil be very inclined to send their kids back."

Some recent graduates reacted by echoing similar sentiments, while older alumni asked what had caused these feelings towards the school. My answer was the following:
Well I think a lot of what's been going wrong has been pretty clear to the alumni through the news articles and stuff. It's not necessarily the diversity issue though, because I think too many resources are being devoted to that when it's not really as big an issue as people think it is, but the deterioration of the admissions process in general. This being combined with the fact that TJ continuously squanders its unique position as the top public school to be a leader actually do something innovative with education in a time when it's become pretty clear that the current public education system in america isn't preparing a large majority of students for the 21st century. So it's not that TJ is a bad school, it's just that it could be so much better but it's become content with staying where it is just because US News continues to rank it as one of the top public schools in america
Since this was rather vague, I was prompted to expand and "suggest any specific changes [I] would like TJ to experiment with rather than being complacent at #1". This was what I suggested:
I just graduated last year, so I don’t want to pretend like I have all the answers, but here are my two cents: 
One thing that really bugged me at TJ was the focus on grades, over actual learning. This lead to a culture of trying to do the least amount of work while still trying to get the highest possible grade which correlates very highly with cheating (and also has an opposite correlation with learning). Instead of me typing it out again I talk about that here:http://www.mjmayank.com/2012/04/on-cheating.html. But to summarize, grades should only be used as a metric for measuring how much a student has learned, not as an incentive (e.g. completion busywork). So that’s one thing.
And as far as the regular classroom goes, I don’t know exactly what they can do to make the classroom experience better but there are a lot of people out there who have plenty ideas. The one thing I do know is that listening to a teacher talk and then reading a textbook for a couple hours isn’t how we learn as human beings, because that’s not how our brains were developed. There are a lot of theories out there on how to incorporate technology and collaboration and gamification to improve education, so maybe we could incorporate them or parts of them. 
Since I mostly followed the computer science track at TJ (and am now studying it in college) I don’t know enough about the other tracks to make many judgments, so I’ll just talk about CS for a little. While I’m extremely fortunate to have been able to study computer science in high school, I feel like after 4 years of taking classes I could’ve ended up a lot further ahead than I ended up (I know basic Java and Python, but don’t know enough to make anything that someone would want to use). Granted, part of that was a lack of initiative on my part. But anyways, since we have the opportunity to learn CS in high school, why not turn that back around and give some other kids the opportunity to learn it in middle school? Or elementary school? Instead of sending kids to tutor math or volunteer just so we can get a TJ face in ever feeder school in the county to serve our own interests of having a more diverse student body, maybe we teach them basic computer science skills and actually add real value. iOS, Android and even Facebook have made developing apps cool, right? Now TJ and FCPS are leaders in the educational community. Where else do you get to learn CS (a talent that’s going to be useful for a long time) at such a young age? Then when these kids are getting ready to go to high school, they’ll realize TJ is the only school that offers computer science courses besides the AP class and decide to apply there.

Anyways, I digress. Being a computer science kid at TJ (or a “syslab kid” as we like to call them) for the most part meant that you ate lunch in the syslab while playing starcraft. So if we could somehow convert the massive amounts of time spent playing starcraft and convert it into productivity, Malcolm Gladwell would be pretty impressed by how many hours of coding experience these kids have before they’ve even graduated from high school. Because the best way to learn CS isn’t in the classroom, it’s by spending time rapidly starting and finishing projects, whether they end up working or not. People do that in college, and they really enjoy it. And it’s the only way to get better. But how would we do this? Have competitions, host hackathons, give out prizes and free food. And I’m sure a lot of companies would be more than happy to sponsor these too. There’s plenty of others things And soon the culture has changed and kids are doing it on their own because now people are using things they’ve made (and there might even be some profit in it for them too). 
Another thing is TJSTAR, which could be mind blowing amazingly awesome, by drawing in the world’s premiere leaders in the science and tech world (I’m talking CEOs, Nobel Prize winners, etc.), but instead it’s a day where they have to convince you to go by making you write about all the panels you went to and turn it in for a grade during your next math class (which most people BS anyways because they’d rather be in the main gym where you can play FIFA on a Kinect or remote control a robot and have it crash into unsuspecting strangers). Maybe I’m dreaming too big but I think a lot of really cool people would be pretty excited to spend a few hours influencing what are supposed to be the smartest high schools engineers in America. Instead we had what was effectively a Microsoft PR guy give the keynote speech in 2011. 
So am I being overly critical? Am I not realizing the value of my education, as another member of the group stated? Or have I highlighted a legitimate problem? Let me know what you think.
item.category: thomas jefferson high school for science and technology

item.title: How to Start Your Own Super PAC (in 5 minutes and for just 45¢)
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
A Super PAC, or an "independent expenditure only committee", is a type of political action committee that is allowed to raise funds to support candidates or policies. It's really simple, and telling someone you're the founder of a Super PAC sounds awesome. Here's how to do it.

Supplies:

1 Envelope
1 Postage stamp
1 FEC Statement of Organization (http://www.fec.gov/pdf/forms/fecfrm1.pdf)

Instructions:

1. Print out the FEC Statement of Organization

2. Fill out the form using the following instructions (don't write anything in the boxes circled in red):

Page 1 
Click to enlarge

A. Come up with a clever name for your Super PAC (Yes, WolfPAC is already taken). For a list of all registered Super PACs, click here. 

B. Write your address. This could be your home address, dorm address or a PO box. 

C. Enter an email address that can be used to contact you. If you create a new one for your PAC, it's probably a good idea to have those emails forwarded to your regular email. 

D. Enter today's date 

E. Check this box 

F. The Treasurer is the only position the FEC actually cares about. Even if you want to call yourself Founder, President, CEO, Beowulf, etc. of your PAC, fill yourself out as treasurer on the form. 



Click to enlarge

Page 2 

G. Check box 5f. Don't do anything else on page 2.
















Click to enlarge
Page 3 


H. Write "None" here. You can't leave this section blank. 

I. Write "Treasurer". 

J. Fill in all your information here. The address can be the same as the one your provided earlier.











Click to enlarge



Page 4 


This entire page can be left blank unless you actually intend to raise funds. If don't intend to but change your mind, you can also submit an amendment later.












3. Fill out this cover letter and include it in the envelope with your forms.


"This committee intends to make independent expenditures, and consistent with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit decision in SpeechNow v. FEC, it therefore intends to raise funds in unlimited amounts. This committee will not use those funds to make contributions, whether direct, in-kind, or via coordinated communications, to federal candidates or committees."


4. Address the envelope to:

Federal Elections Commission
999 E Street, NW
Washington, DC 20463


Since most of you have probably never sent a letter in the mail before, don't forget to put the correct postage (45¢ or a Forever Stamp) and write a return address in the top left corner.


In about a week you should get an email from the FEC notifying you that your registration has been received. Congrats! You can now raise funds in unlimited amounts (as long as you don't give it to a political party or spend it in direct corroboration with a candidate, and file quarterly spending and earning reports with the FEC listing the names of your donors and their contributions)

Mayank Jain is the founder of Leader of the PAC. He is currently a freshman at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, studying Computer Science. Follow him on twitter @mjmayank1.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks Mayank. Good job. We'll see how it goes.
Does anyone have a affective example or template for an amendment letter to start fundraising?
Do I need this cover letter if I might down the road donate to candidates?
My printing does not show which ones are in red. Also is this the most updated form?

Do I need a pre approval permission from the IRS and a special status, such as becoming a not for profit person/Organization? What kind of bank account do I use for all the activities I would like to do?

item.title: Graduation Speech: Leaving a Legacy
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
"About two weeks, I was sitting in Topics class listening to final project presentations. My friend Varun turns to me and goes, “Man, I really love what you’re doing with your hair.” You can’t really see it under this ridiculous hat, but I usually gel my hair up a little in the front. So on a whim, I tell him “Dude, we should get every to gel their hair up tomorrow, and call it Fauxhawk Friday” So we go home and make a facebook event and invite people to join us.

Well I get to school tomorrow, and I see fauxhawks everywhere. The thing about TJ kids, is they find pleasure in the smallest things. But it wasn’t just that. People were helping each other put their fauxhawks up. They brought in bottles of gel so that others could do it when they go to school. Because TJ is really a community of friendship. While we might have all come to TJ for different reasons, this was why we stayed.

For the last four years we’ve taken everything that TJ has to offer. We’ve taken opportunities, memories, knowledge. Our impact, however, will be measured not by what we took, but by what we gave. As our time here comes to end, we look back and hope that we’ve left more behind than just footsteps in the hallways. Whether it’s the traditions we started, the friends we’ve made (“where’s the Guild at”), or the things we’ve accomplished, we’ve all made our own contributions to the TJ community.

Many of us are going to go on to do amazing things. Within just a small sample, you could find the next Mark Zuckerberg or Nobel Prize winner or a future president. You might also find Shriram though, so be careful. But, in some sense of the word, we are all going to be successful.

Photo courtesy of Grace Clark
But what does it really mean to be successful? Can we define it by our grade point average for the last four years? Can we define it by the universities we’ll be attending this fall? Can we define it by the job we work or the amount of money we make in our lifetimes? I don’t think that really cuts it. A wise man once said, success is living your life in a way that causes you to feel a ton of happiness and very little pain - and because of your lifestyle, have the people around you feel a lot more happiness than they do pain.

Just two months ago, we experienced the tragic passing of our fellow classmate and friend, Zach Brunt. I didn’t know Zach. I wish I did. Seeing the things you all said about him, the support you all showed. It takes a certain caliber person to elicit that response. But what was it that we remembered about him? It wasn’t how well he did in school or how amazing his research was. People said things like, “He always said hi to me in the hallways”, “He reached out to me when I was a freshman”, “He brightened the mood of any room that he entered.” It’s the things we do to make other people’s lives better that defines our legacy

As we continue to take steps forward of our life, we must think about what it is that we leaving behind. Success, as they say, is not to be pursued; it is to be attracted by the person we become. What matters in the end is not that we do something special, but that we be something special. Then, and only then, can we truly be successful."

The speech was given at Thomas Jefferson High School's graduation ceremony on June 16th, 2012

Mayank Jain is a freshman at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, studying Computer Science. Follow him on twitter at mjmayank1.
item.category: thomas jefferson high school for science and technology

item.title: College Essay
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
This was the essay I submitted for the Common App of my college application:

Evaluate a significant experience, achievement, risk you have taken, or ethical dilemma you have faced and its impact on you.

I was standing on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange drinking from a reusable water bottle lined with a gel that kills bacteria. The inventor stood in front of me explaining how it could help alleviate the lack of potable water in developing countries. Five minutes later, I was standing at the next booth listening to a woman who collects micro-donations for community building projects in Africa, and later that day I sat down for coffee with a recent MIT graduate who designed a vehicle shock absorber that converts bumps in the road into energy. Over the course of a few hours, I met fifty different people whose crazy ideas were changing the world.

One of the most inspiring and eye-opening experiences of my life was the first time I attended the Kairos Society Global Summit. The focus of the summit is social entrepreneurship—bringing entrepreneurs together from all over the globe to solve the world’s biggest problems.

While tackling global issues is already admirable, the most amazing thing about the conference was that these entrepreneurs weren’t executives of multi-million dollar companies. They were all still in college. I realized that it doesn’t take a PhD and a million dollars of funding to solve society’s most basic obstacles. All it takes is an understanding that something is wrong in the world and a desire to fix it.

The summit showed me that entrepreneurship isn’t about the amount of profit you make, but the number of lives you touch. When all is said and done, people aren’t going to remember us for our money, but because of the difference we’ve made in their lives. If I live with this mindset, it will prepare me to give back for the rest of my life.

With the privilege of being one of three high school invitees to the summit, I’ve worked to bring these ideas back to my school. As president of the Future Business Leaders of America club, I encourage our members to start their own ventures and invite established entrepreneurs to mentor them. Working with the student government, I organized a leadership seminar that brings together the most influential students leaders at my school to ensure that we are creating an environment that maximizes the potential of our peers. With my cousin, I started a non-profit that leverages the power of social media for social good. My goal is to bring the principles of Kairos one step closer, to the high school level, and get my peers thinking about entrepreneurship at an earlier age.

Standing among such amazing people at the conference opened my eyes to the fact that it takes a little bit of crazy to change the world. Hopefully, I’ll use the little bit of crazy that’s in me to do something meaningful. Then, when I return to the Kairos Summit, I’ll be on the other side of the booth, telling a wide-eyed high schooler how I’m changing the world.

Mayank Jain is a freshman at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, studying Computer Science. Follow him on twitter at mjmayank1.

item.title: TJ Students
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
Whenever TJ gets some negative press from an external location, such as the Washington Post, TJ students are quick to defend both their school and themselves. When news is released less publically, such as the recently published demographics of the incoming class of 2016, TJ students are much more critical.

Most of the news about TJ, as well as the demographics of the incoming class are focused on one thing: diversity. While most people refuse to identify themselves as the type of student the articles typically describe or claim that the diversity problem has only begun to develop after their class was selected, the accuracy of the stereotype of a typical TJ student surprises me. It’s amazing to see the amount of students at this school who take subjects that don’t interest them simply to receive an extra AP credit, who participate in extracurricular activities that don't interest them “because they look good on college applications”, and who begin studying for the SAT in middle school or freshman year.

For the last three years, I have attended the Kairos Society Global Summit, which brings together the top college entrepreneurs from around the world for a weekend of brainstorming and networking. I was given a taste of the type of student who does well, and yet still manages to make a lasting impact on society. While obviously college students have valuable experiences that many high school students don’t possess yet, I noticed a stark contrast between the shy, studious nature of TJ students and the charisma and intelligence of these budding entrepreneurs.

With an awareness of Jefferson alumni along with my knowledge of its student body, I've come to the conclusion that the students that leave TJ aren’t the ones that are going to change the world; they’re just going to do really well in college.

Mayank Jain is a freshman at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, studying Computer Science. Follow him on twitter at mjmayank1.
item.category: thomas jefferson high school for science and technology

item.title: On Cheating
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
Recently last week I got in trouble for cheating in stat class. The infraction I had committed was working with other students to complete an assignment that was worth six points and graded on completion. Four of us got in trouble, and even more should have. The surprising thing was, after our teacher pulled us outside and talked to us, I realized that I didn’t even feel bad for cheating. However, administrators obviously want to discourage this type of behavior, and I agree that it’s an issue that needs to be addressed. The problem is, the issue is so deeply engrained in the culture of the school, that the only way to fix it requires a fundamental change in the structure of the grade system.

TJ students are notoriously obsessed with grades. A common anecdote students hear early in their TJ career is the one about Mr. McFaden, sex, and extra credit (http://www.tjbash.org/1084). TJ students do things to improve their grade. Teachers know this, students know this, and administration knows this. Everyone knows this. This fact however, has caused teachers to become lazy. Rather than making sure lesson plans are interesting and keep students engaged, they expect students to pay attention simply because the information will be on a test. They expect students to do their homework because it’s worth points. Teachers don’t have to make sure that the worksheets they give out or the assignments they assign are interesting, because giving a grade for them has been so effective that TJ students will do them regardless.

This is why cheating has become such a big problem at TJ. Teachers incentivize students with grades, so students do things that get them good grades. The process of learning is simply intermediary. Sure, sometimes (or the majority of the time) it’s the easiest way to get a good grade. But when we see an opportunity to skip that step, it becomes second nature to do so. By copying the worksheet I got the grade. It was faster and easier than actually learning the statistics involved and completing the problems myself.

So how do we fix the system? Teachers need to stop leaning on the crutch that grades have become, and carefully moderate the content they teach in class and the medium in which they present it. They must make an effort to keep class interesting and only handout homework that they believe is absolutely necessary to student’s educational development. Grades should not be used as an incentive, but as a metric. Grades need to return to the role they were originally designed to do: to measure how much a student has learned. This is, of course, no easy task. It requires a culture change from the top to the bottom, administration to teachers to students, as well as throughout the school and county. We can’t stop cheating simply by outlawing it. That just means we’ll have to police it. We have to stop cheating by making it pointless and counterproductive.

Mayank Jain is a freshman at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, studying Computer Science. Follow him on twitter at @mjmayank1.
item.category: thomas jefferson high school for science and technology

item.title: FBLA Emails
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
"Officers:
Today’s standing officer lunch meeting AGAIN didn’t happen. P------ came in, saw no one and left. C---- can in, spoke with me and left. This comes during the same week that no one remembered to get volunteers for the pizza fundraiser until I sent an e-mail on Monday, and no one would have been available to help me with the pizzas and cash box if I didn’t have Wills in my first block class. I intend to cancel next Wednesday’s fundraiser because I’m too busy to have to worry about a lack of support.
This past Wednesday, we had a non-activity activity. Without an officer meeting, there will be no activity next week. The fundraising activities for MOD are non-existent, and I found it completely inappropriate that points for the Odio Challenge were promised that make our entire program of work a joke. Promising to double existing point totals for one Odio experience makes all the small point tasks useless and discounts all the hard work members have done to letter all year.
As you already know, the Service Week Challenge was a joke. We raised nothing and did nothing. All it seemed to be was a opportunity for one officer to get his name in the limelight. Very sad.
A lot of the problem has been that all decisions were centralized in the presidency early in the year. When that officer ceased to care, a power vacuum developed. Another officer was assigned MOD. Nothing’s happened.
I cannot pick up after you from now until the end of the year. If I don’t see immediate improvement, I will consider suspending  the current officer corps and call for an immediate election of new officers. We can’t get through the year with NO leadership. We still have the lead-up to MOD, T-shirt design and purchase decisions, the lettering ceremony, and elections.
I am therefore calling an emergency officer meeting on Tuesday next week at lunch in Room 107. We need to figure out how to handle this power vacuum. If the current officers no longer wish to serve, they should be replaced immediately.
I am dedicated to getting this chapter through the year. After that, who knows. I have been very disappointed with the lack of spirit for some time."
"When I was first elected as president of FBLA at the end of my sophomore year, I was given one piece of advice from the incumbent president as he stepped down from his role: "Watch out for Mrs. ------." When I spoke to those who served on the officer corps from the year before that, they echoed similar sentiments. Many of the problems you address (lack of activities, member apathy) have been problems FBLA has faced for many years especially around this time of the year, long before the current officer corps was elected. Changes were suggested at the beginning of this year (limiting membership, altering the lettering points system) but they were all rebuked, with the assumption that those problems wouldn't be an issue this time.
As the club addresses the issues in leadership among the officers, this can be an opportunity to reflect on your own leadership style as well. Meetings often occur outside in the hallway because the officers know entering your classroom invites criticism and condemnation. When new ideas or initiatives are proposed the impulse is to reject them rather than seeing how they can be improved or fit into the existing program of work. This creates a constricted environment in which the expectation is that every year be just like the year before, rather than encouraging creativity.
While I wish I could finish my senior year leading this organization, I believe the time has come for me to step down. In the best interest of the club and its members, I would like to resign as President of FBLA.
Sincerely,
Mayank Jain"

item.title: How to Win Facebook Friends and Influence People: The Foolproof Way to Get Likes on Facebook
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
First of all, in order for this to work the post needs to be reasonably witty, clever, or funny. After you post your status, wait a little bit until it gets a couple likes all by itself. If it doesn't get any or it's only your mom, this wouldn't have worked anyways.

But once it does, "like" your own status. Then wait a couple minutes for it to get a couple more likes. The best thing that can happen is someone will notice that you liked your own status and point it out while attempting to make fun of you. Once this happens, unlike your post and say something like "dude wtf are you talking about", or some other statement showing incredulousness (Yeah, incredulity isn't a word. This is the only noun form of incredulous).
Lil Wayne probably used this strategy

But, if no one points out that you liked your own status, don't fret! The situation can be salvaged. Just ask one of your friends to point it out and it'll have the same effect. Then continue from the part where you pretend to be incredulous.

Using this strategy will drastically increase the amount of likes on your post, usually pushing it into double digits! It'll work, trust me.

Hit up the comments if this worked for you. Or if you thought the title of this blog post was clever.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I used to never get comments or likes on my wall posts, then I read the blogpost, "How to Win Facebook Friends and Influence People: The Foolproof Way to Get Likes on Facebook," and now I get double digits likes and comments everytime! Thanks Mayank, you really helped my social life launch through the roof!
this is a really interesting topic! i like to like my own things too.
can we, your loyal readers, expect a book anytime soon? :D

your blog really shows off your feminine side mayank, keep up the good work!

-your beloved follower

I found myself engaged in the words. You
Spoke very eloquently. I thought the
Hinting about Lil Wayne was clever.

Do you think you will write a book?
Or possibly a FB page?
Even a movie is possible?

item.title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded:
Over the summer I started reading the book The Immortal life of Henrietta Lacks for TJ's One Question, "How can we, the TJ community, take action to prepare students to confront difficult moral and ethical decisions, both now and in the future?" (Why the One Question even exists is beyond me) However I got about halfway through the book when I realized I didn't agree with the fact that the scientists had done anything unethical. The book makes the argument that when the hospital asked Henrietta Lack's husband, David, for permission to use her cells he refused to sign the statement. Therefore the hospital had no right to take or experiment on her cells.

But if those scientists hadn't taken her cells, imagine how much worse off we'd be. The cells were instrumental in the creation of the polio vaccine and they've been used in cancer, AIDS, the effects of radiation and toxic substances, and gene mapping research. Would it really have been better if they'd respected David's wishes and stopped using her cells (he had no reason for saying no either, he just didn't feel like it)?

The book also makes the argument that the Lacks family deserves some monetary compensation because of the amount of profit derived from research on Lacks cells. I don't entirely agree with this conclusion either. Sure it would've been a nice symbolic gesture for the scientists to have given some money to the remaining Lacks family, but I don't think they needed to. Based on my limited understanding of intellectual property law (and I do believe the cells should be considered intellectual property because they have no inherent value and they're infinite), you have to not only prove that something was stolen, but also that it affected your ability to profit in the marketplace. There is literally no way the Lacks could have profited from Henriettas cells on her own. They wouldn't have even known that her cells were in any way different from their own cells.

The book also brings up the fact that the Lacks' are black and insinuates that they were mistreated because of it. But judging by the author's recount of her treatment at the colored ward of John Hopkins Hospital, she received not only what appears to be the best treatment an African American cancer patient could receive at the time, but on par with any treatment a white person would've received. Cancer treatment just wasn't very effective back then. The fact that they were black also doesn't play into the fact that they were uncompensated for their cells. Everyone who checked into hospital had their cells sent to George Gey for research and no one received compensation, black or white. As Thomas Jefferson said, "He who receives an idea from me, receives instruction himself without lessening mine; as he who lights his taper at mine, receives light without darkening me." Same thing applies here.

Remember that I've only read half the book. Did I overlook some blatant ethical infraction that the author mentions? Have I misinterpreted the author's recollection of the events? Should I read the second half of the book? Do you have no idea what I'm talking about because you've never read this book? Did I misuse the word literally in the 3rd paragraph? Am I asking too many questions to try and get you to comment?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Interesting. A valid argument, perhaps the root of the problem lies within education.

item.title: How to Get Your Own Seat on the Bus
item.dc:creator: mjmayank
item.content:encoded: This is a continuation of the series Nice Guys Finish Last. The previous post can be found at "How to Cut in Line" One of the staples of college life is the bus/train ride to get back home for the holidays. Unfortunately, riding public transportation usually means sitting just inches away from a complete stranger for a few hours and the unfortunate ritual of making awkward small talk. There is however a way to prevent this and get an extra seat for yourself. Here's how to do it: Sit in the aisle seat and place your bag on the window seat. Attempt to make your bag appear as large and bulky as possible. Try a couple positions and see which one makes it look the largest. Just to stress, it's important that you sit in the aisle seat, because this would cause anyone sitting down to either have you move to the window seat or climb over you. Most people have a tendency to try and create as little disruption to their surrounding environment as possible. Take advantage of that. Now establish your presence. Take out your laptop/tablet/book (laptop is best because it would the most inconvenient to put away and is probably the largest) and a set of headphones. You don't even have to be listening to anything necessarily. Headphones in your ear is just the international symbol for don't bother me. Once you're set up, make sure you don't look relaxed. Scrunch over your device as if you're busy and stressed. Avoid eye contact with anyone that walks by. Eye contact invites them to initiate a conversation with you and you want to make that difficult to do. They'll just pick someone else if it's a struggle to get your attention. Don't let your guard down until the bus starts moving, especially if the bus gets close to capacity. The last few empty seats are always the hardest to protect. You can easily get your own extra seat every time you travel just by using these simple tips and tricks. Or as my friend Burke Deutsch so eloquently puts it, just be the asshole you wouldn't want to sit next to. Remember though, if the bus is full then move your stuff and graciously accept defeat. Or just buy two tickets next time. Mayank Jain actually writes these bylines about himself in 3rd person. Follow him on twitter at @mjmayank1.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: the picture is my favorite part. it really emphasizes your points.
